Letter from my beloved daughter-in-law who died after radical bilateral mastectomies Oct., 1966 KKM
Jan 9, 1956
Dear Great Gram,
We are enjoying the fruit you sent very much - They are beautiful oranges and very delicious.
We are all fine. I suppose Katherine has told you that we are expecting a new addition to the family the last of June. We are very happy about it of course -
The children are doing just fine in school. Sally has been going to nursery school in the mornings and just loves it. I have the mornings all to myself but seem to find plenty to do. Marvin seems to keep busy with this and that around the house on weekends too. We hope to decorate (paint) the living room and dining room this spring if possible.

Went to drugstore and bought a blank for deed. Took it to Mrs. Elizabeth Mizelle to type and notarize. She did the Old Age paper and Cora & Clarence witnessed it, and Mr Mizelle promised to mail it for me to Mrs. Williamson. Then we got our groceries - Cora had lots of errands and in doing them she lost a report that Mildred had left with her to see 3 different Woodmen's Circle women to check with, so she went back to the drugstore to hunt it up and Clarence brought me home - groceries $4.67. Am keeping track to see how near I come to living within my income.
Yesterday morning I heard a story during the Coffee Hour and an ad. for Ever-ready batteries, of a man whose life was saved from the attack of a grizzly bear at Yellowstone Pk. The m.c. asked for stories from others as to the merits of the Ever-ready batteries. So I bethought me of the time they saved me from being sprinkled by a skunk, and at 3 a.m. - I got up and wrote out the story and mailed it to W.DBO. Orlando when I went to the p.o. I asked them to let me know if they rec. the story. As I hadn't heard the first part of the program I don't know whether or not they offer to pay for the stories. hope they do,l and that I get some sponduliks [slang for cash] for it.
Also, at Mrs. Mizelles I left a blank for warranty deed for you which Elizabeth will type, etc., for me.) cooked some beet greens and had some rice I cooked this a.m. and a piece of cherry pie I bot at A.& P. They do make delicious cherry pies and for only 38 cents. Also made myself a cup of instant coffee from your jar of Maxwell House, with plenty of sugar and Carnation milk to keep myself awake in case the ladder is delivered this aft - And I'm so sleepy now I can hardly see!! It probably will keep me awake all night as that happened the time before that I tried it. Weather so mild I've had no fire of any sort today. Cora said that Larrie will not be able to go to school for 4 or 5 months, and her dog Judy is in the hospital to be put to sleep.

Friday 9 a.m. Jan 20, '56
Darling Tafern,
Have just rec'd this letter and while I'm waiting for Cora and Clarence to come, I'll begin my letter to you. I laughed like everything over that cartoon. Wish we had as good an artist here!
The weather modulated and has been livable without the woodstove the last 2 or 3 days. Predictions are for a return tonight, but we have no clouds today so I don't see how it can freeze soon.
I hate to admit it, but no oranges picked yet. Sometimes I feel like climbing and picking them myself -- but the hospital looms up, so I don't try.
Maybe that fruit is the tangelo, now. Tangelos are abt as big as grape fruit, lemon color, few seeds and sweet. tangerines are small, thin skin so you can pull it off easily and divisions are easily eaten without a lot of juice, and they are deeper color than oranges.
Shall be very interested to know the reactions to the Three Bears after next Sunday. Wish I could see those Disney pictures. I subscribed for Marlene to have the little mag pub'd at Poukipsee (N.Y. poor spelling) [Poughkeepsie] of Disney's cartoons. Cora has ---- Cashed the p.o. got 99 cents of 3rd and book of air mail stamps. Then to bank and deposited $28.00 of the Old Age acct - am buying a new ladder 22 ft at 30 cents per to be delivered, and maybe the boys who deliver will do the picking. Cora engineered all this, and told Keller ( the man who sold the ladder) that she would pay for it if I didn't want it.

Mrs. May Walden
420 West Bell Street
Avon Park, Fla.        1-26-'56
Darling Tafern
Dated my last letter one day behind. Mr. Massy took mixed basket for Hayes yesterday aft. I revise my statement of yesterday's letter. Charge Hayes same as the others - $6.00. I picked the grape fruit myself, washed and packed it and filled the upper half with sweet navels and on top enough June bloom to fill up.
Wrote a letter to Malcolm and told him he could call it a birthday gift instead of a Christmas gift, and enclosed a jar of guava jelly. Yours had quomquot preserves that Mrs. Beyer gave me months ago.
Malcolm will be 39. Hope it gets there on his birthday.
Turned cold in the night so this a.m. 40 degrees put on the old union suit again. Sent to Sears for 2 suits of high-neck shirt and long pants, so hope you have

Also I invested in a new can opener as the one you gave me doesn't cut through sometimes. I have had a world of good out of it and always use it with love to you. It has been such a help.
Went over for few minutes to Mrs. Beyer's yest aft. to take Look to them. They seem to like it, and I don't care to keep them. Don't read all of it at any time. Find Time much more interesting and helpful, tho I cuss part of the time when reading it. Had to laugh the way Luce apologized and blamed himself for Dulles damned stupidity! Then Dulles smeared himself all over again by repeating and asserting - Oh Holy Mither! A rather pathetic picture of Eisenhower in this morning's Trib - Poor old ninny, if he knows where he is well off he will stay on his farm and enjoy his last days there. He will surely pass out if he runs again, and Nixon is making sure he will be President anyhow.
Warming up. Lovely sunshine. House warm and everything O.K.
Much love,
Mother

2-12-'56
Darling Tafern,
Yes, your letter with $5.00 enc - came Saturday morning and (Thanks very much for the five, but I didn't need it) I was very happy to have it. These slippery days- you know, and I can't help worrying some.
Have been holding Tom most all morning as he is in cat heaven when I do - I manage to have a paper or book near as my time isn't altogether lost. Poor Muldoon, I'm sorry for his frustration. I feel like apologizing to Laddie, for he is such a handsome cat. But look at Tom! His beauty is spoiled I'm afraid However the injury is healing over, am wondering if the hair will grow on his new skin?!
I don't blame Muldoon for keeping an eye on the gold fish - I'm sure they would taste pretty good. 
You will be interested in my last escapade. Life begins at 90, you know! This sheet I'm writing on tells the story. Instead of enclosing a dollar for the cat bed I sent about 20 labels and suggested that since I had had dozens of same, maybe they would send it anyway.
So glad you've seen Malcolm again and that he is enjoying the fruit. He hasn't written yet.
written on the side for them  - Hope L. will not do any of that painting she wrote about, Much love, Mother

MRS. MAY WALDEN
420 WEST BELL STREET
AVON PARK, FLA
8:00 a.m.
7-29-56
Darling Tafern

   Just saw in T T - Tampa Tribune that Mrs. Perry passed away yesterday! 
    Am hurrying to apt. at hairdressers to be with Mildred as she goes this aft. by plane for San Juan -- and tomorrow is her 42 b-day. She was my first baby here in A. P.. 
                            Much love
                                     Mother

Thanks much for stationery!!
Vertical in left margin: Mother was a practical nurse from 1913 on for some years and this girl was her 1st baby case. K.K.M.

Monday, March 12, 1956.
Darling Tafern,
A lot of activities the past few days! Cora has a renter who is quite a person. A vet of W.W.I, an inspector of W.W. II, a much travelled Scotchman 78 years old, but not rugged, jolly and sociable, Mr David Hobbin (I think) has taken us to Lake Placid and to Cypress Gardens and Bok Sanctuary last Friday and yesterday. At Lake Placid we called on Mrs Seaverus for a few minutes. She was having the annual committee meeting for something, so we didn't go in. She was looking very well and she gave me a large package. We went around the town, and I went into a dry goods store and bought material for a dress. Mrs. Renfro will make it for me. At Cypress Gardens we saw the water gymnastics and skiing - very wonderful, and acres of beautiful flowers, now at their best, along with the perfume of the citrus trees. The weather was

Darling Tafern,
The place for the N.Y. Symphony is taken by baseball this aft. so here goes.  Thanks for Hick's basket. Cora and Clarence came for me before the mail was delivered that brought my 4th O.A.A. check, so the $6 00 came in very handily.
Was it necessary for Miss Mallory's health that she had to have a drink of tea before the Union meeting? There is nothing more unappetizing than cold mashed potato, seems to me, but since chicken can be eaten hot or cold, that doesn't matter so much -  and congealed gravy! O My! Well. I'm glad you could play for them
I happened to have old Mr. Campbell here, scattering fertilizer and hoeing it in, so got him to pick enough g.f. for you - I have only one bushel basket left and it is for your next bushel, so I guess you'd better not get orders from Hicks and Rhea. Sorry, for now that I have the 22 foot ladder, I could have the tree all

MRS. MAY WALDEN
420 West Bell Street
Avon Park, Fla.
4-17-'56
Darling Tafern,
I was out last evening until 9:40 at Mrs. Riffles, looking at colored pictures that her son Henry and his wife Dot showed on their screen. Most of them taken at Watkin's Glen N.Y. where they live, and surrounding vicinity. a few takes in A.P. including my dwarf poinciania bush, an orange and g.f. tree and several of his mother and Georgie - all very beautiful pictures. He is certainly a master photographer. He brought me and the flash light home as soon as it was all over. They went out today to photograph and have just got back, it's a lovely sunshiny day.

I bought a ticket for Wm Pickett, the younger boy, and when he was through weeding and I offered him the ticket in pay, he refused to take it. Said he would be whipped if he went and James said they were going to Ft. Meade with his older brother "on a vacation," so they couldn't go. I gave the ticket to Mrs. Renfro to give to anyone, and I paid Wm 20 cents for his weeding. I had to pretty nearly stand over him and point out the weeds to get the job half-decently done. At first he wanted a match so he could smoke. I gave him a stick of gum instead and he kept complaining that he must go home else he'd get whipped. I asked him who would whip him at that hour - just after school. He said "My Dad." But he wouldn't be home now, if he's working." He insisted that he would, so I gave up. The mother is still having treatments at the hospital, and no way of paying for them, I asked that the Welfare and Health lady be questioned again and some report be made again on the situation.
I have my electric clock back and rejoice. I missed it terribly. Cora and Clarence brought it yesterday aft. and took away more than 1/2 bushel of g.f. that I had saved for them. Clarence leaves next Monday. Cora will be very glad as he is so cantankerous when she asks a favor of him. Her boy-friend leaves next Tuesday, and she will certainly miss his sympathy and helpful ways. He plans to go back, sell his home and be down again in a month, but he is not a well man and I told her to not expect to

MRS. MAY WALDEN
420 West Bell Street
Avon Park, Fla.
4-24-'56
Darling Tafern,
Echo from the Z-Donahue mixtry. You gave the right address, and I'm sure I did. should have put the Z. name as well as the D. Re the phone address: I feel confident now that I have the right address, so things are all straight now.
Sorry about the Scott brother's death. Hope he was well enough to do that he left his family comfortable -- as I suppose he had one.  I shall be very glad to see the girls when they come this way. Both fine girls! The only 16 year old girl I know is Martha Renfro. She is v.p. of her Junior class, plays in the band, rides the horse in a quadrille, makes her own clothes from the instructions in Home Ec. and altogether a fine, busy girl. Don't see how she could give Maxine much attention, but maybe she could help and find others. I've put the description of the ruler I want up on a separate piece of paper for your purse. Hope he will be willing to give it to you. He has no use for it now.

    Cora said she went to the Hospital with dominic and found things in an awful mess. Mrs. P. has developed a bed sore. They had tied her hands but she got loose, tore off the bandages and scratched, etc.
    Forgot to give you the outline of the girl's trip. They went down the East Coast to Miami. Left their car there and took a bus to Key West. Intended to go to Cuba, but I guess it was the day of the insurrection, so they couldn't get a plane. When they left home they had a notion of taking stuff along that they could cook, but found it impossible, so they donated 6 apples, 4 big onions, some potatoes, case of pine apple chunks, case of chicken soup, & some sour milk.
    I made apple sauce at once after they left and have planted the sprouted onion. Now have 4 onion plants and one tomato plant still bearing --

5-31-'56
Darling Tafern,
I've given a lot of time the last week to reading Eleanor Farrar's Journal of her African trip.  It is absorbing, not only for the perusal but for the research.  I've had 2 atlas's by me all the time and have consulted the ency dictionary constantly to get out of it something  of what she put into it.  In spite of the mishaps, misinformation and rudeness of officials, etc - she encountered, she stuck doggedly to her determination to see Africa.  I get a good idea of the continent now, where before my ideas were hazy.  She went clear to Cape-town and up and down the Coasts away, then saw the Victoria Falls on her way up.  At the equator - which she doesn't mention - it was only 90° but from there, Nairobi, to Cairo and back to Luxor - the land of the pyramids, mummies, etc - she found filth, squalor and beggars.  Then she had a bad accident at Cairo and it was wheel-chair and help from her guides after that.  Tho she didn't give up the trip to Portugal, after suffering at Istanbul and Rome.  She liked Portugal best of all.  It was so clean after Egypt and Turkey that she'd like to go back for a vacation there.
Along the side of the page  Thanks for Laura's card.  Please send her address!

I've nearly finished the second reading of the 28 type written single space M.S. She sent stamps for return postage but there is no hurry for its return. To finish answering your 5-23 letter I think your advice to Jr. abt. joining the Navy is sound. He can educate himself for any occupation he is fitted for, and if he chooses his companions carefully he can be a respected, honorable citizen when his time is up. Did he seem to accept your suggestion? Bookie, according to previous schedules, took her family away for 3 or 4 days but brought them back yesterday. They have adopted the apt. landing for their home, so I put their food at the top of the stairs. But the little yellow one is so frightened that he jumps down to the ground and runs off toward Renfro's when I appear. Mr. R. who by the way is showing himself a wonderfully helpful neighbor and has fixed 3 leaky faucets for me, without pay, has found a home for the little white kitten. The little girl of a Frost-proof friend of Mr. R.'s, had a white kitten that got killed and she is grieving so over the loss that Mr. R. has promised to get another. The problem - how to catch it! I suggested a swarm of children could get it, and hope to see it done. Much love Mother.
In left margin: Mrs. Mizelle took me to vote Tuesday. Voted for Stevenson.

Darling Tafern:
So happy to have your card this morning.  I'm thinking of you in Indiana now, almost home - I hope you find Muldoon all well and active - I have just buried Laddie - I was napping after cleaning the bathroom when two small Renfro boys came and asked if I owned a big white cat.  Then they said "He's dead" - I went with them - He was lying near the bench the Renfro's have near their lemon bush.  Evidently he had been dead several hours for Mr. Renfro said he wasn't home last night else he would have seen him.  I found where the old cat had her kittens just after you left.  I followed her - Back of "s" scratched out Singleterry's garage under some loose boards.  The two white kittens disappeared as I came closer, and this morning the mother cat ran under their house when I told the boys where I had seen them -

Mr. Hobbins drives them to Tampa tomorrow then Mildred takes the plane for Puerto Rico.  Mr. Hobbins has promised to call for me every Friday at nine to get my groceries. I'm sorry you didn't go to Sebring right away.  Have forgotten the osteopath's name.  Hope situation o.k.  All my love,

after dinner, Thanksgiving '56
Darling Tafern,

  Forgot to show you this letter when you were here. I've just ans'd it. This is a fine sunny day but a little cool after several weeks of above normal temperatures
    Mrs. Riffle came in Monday to ask if I would room two friends of hers who were to spend Thanksgiving week with her. They came yesterday and were here last night. Very pleasant old ladies. One is Mrs. R's daughter-in-law's mother. The other a working nurse when Mrs. R - knew when they were girls. She still takes cases, is a widow of 10 years, has 2 married daughters, owns some valuable antique furniture in a big home and she comes to Fla. every winter, but never here before. Think she usually winters in St. Petersburg. I find her interesting.

aft - Left home by cab at 1:45 decd walked
home with the street lights burning just
before 6:  A play that is one of the 2 or

recall my stories of the - Napoleonic Wars

couldn't help comparing them to the
sufferings of the French soldiers on their
retreat from burning Moscow.  Hope you
see it and think Max would like it too.

get many thrills.  She wondered why I was
downtown that time of day!
Last Friday aft.  Mrs Krause called.  She
walked both ways and amazes me at her
recovery. She said the Episcopal rector
who has been here at least 2 years, has
gone to Sanford and didn't come over
to see her - "Well," she said "I'm not much
for church anyway.  They don't know

11-21-'58
Darling Tafern,
Home at three after a delightful luncheon at the home of an old lady - not so old as I am - Mrs. Stewart, a friend of Mabel's whom I met at luncheon at Mabel's one hot day last summer. Mrs. Kinner, who owns the black cat named Teddy, was there also. All ladies are Episcopalians, with nice soft voices so I don't hear half what they say, but they are all lovely to me and treat me with almost reverence. I wore my girdle, and when I put my stockings on, I put on garters to hold them up until I can get the fasteners firmly anchored to the stockings,

Darling Tafern,

 Thanks for the Time Magazines - I found a number of interesting things in them, especially time on Guana. The tribes are having quite a time there now,

and I do not hear from An?piah. Won't Dulles have a bigger belly ache than ever if he can't go to his meting in Paris?! We may be better off if he can't/

 Mildred got Mrs. Ross safely to the rest home in Winter Haven, and she leaves for Puerto Rico early Monday morning. Cora telephoned me that she is

Leora said she has gained 5 lbs since she came home from the hospital.

Darling Tafern,
So you recall my telling you last Sept. about the letters I have kept from several people like Tom Mooney .etc and that I wanted to send these to the Nearings for historical purpose? And you asked "why don't we express them at once"? And I replied "I'd have to write to them first." Well I wrote and Helen replied they had no room for anything as they had several hundred of their own publications. I let the matter drop until recently where I felt it necessary to do something about this matter, so I wrote Nate Berlyn for suggestions. An airmail letter came Saturday saying he had telephoned the librarian of Newberry library asking if they would take them - As soon as the librarian found out who I am,
top margin
Monday, Will spend some time looking further for things I think suitable.  Weather fine little cool.  all o.k.

MRS. MAY WALDEN
420 West Bell Street
Avon Park, Fla.

 April 12, 1959 -

Darling Tafern,

 My collection went off, express collect, last Tuesday, and not one of your letters was enclosed. But I had

my old steamer trunk full (except the tray) and asked that it be sent to you when emptied. I never expect to use
it again, so I thought it might as well be at your place. Of course I haven't heard anything yet from the Librarian.

 I can imagine how busily you are working to organize your shipment, as have not expected any word from you since

[[on side]:  Toby caught a few red-headed woodpeckers this a.m. - Dead when he came in else I wd have taken it away from him.

"the Quickie." It came in plenty time, and everything was and is, O.K.   Mabel came over yesterday afternoon and after a visit of half an hour, or so, had to run

 had a nice letter from Clare enclosing the school picture of Marlene. What a bright, attractive little girl she is! and such beautiful hair!  Clara seems to enjoy getting letters

The news item that has interested me the most this past week is the death of Frank Lloyd Wright. He was Jenkin Lloyd Jones nephew, and everybody knew him as an eratic

young scamp. I had a long talk with his first and I think, followed by three others - wife and she had no children.  I was canvassing for something at the time in Oak Park,
and she was living in the house he built around a tree, and sadly waiting for his return. He had been away about a year, then, but she was doubtfully hoping. Shortly after
we heard that he had started a home in Wisc. with another woman: Later, was the awful tragedy, printed in the  C.T. (Tampa Tribune) that I remember well - I never saw
him, but the Unitarians have plenty to talk about, out of his uncle's hearings who

disowned him. He had a bad influence over Jenkin Lloyd Jones II who had quite a time sowing his wild oats. But jr. finally settled down and was publishing a paper
in Texas or somewhere. I have not seen any items about him for several years, so maybe he has passed on.

 The Pickett boys have turned up again. The youngest one, red haired, freckled, very unattractive,turned up asking for yard work. I put him thru the sprouts in weeding the grass roots from my hibiscus bushes, and finally got one bush weeded pretty well. He  also cut up the trunk of the old King orange tree that blew over in Feb 7:15 pm.

Had a big surprise this aft. Jean Hill and Leila with her 15 mos. baby girl, Bettie and Ethel came for 15 minutes or so. All are looking fine. She said the boys are growing
tall also. Jean still in the drugstore - Asked about you, and to come to see her at the drugstore when you come.    Much Love, Mother.

MRS. MAY WALDEN
420 West Bell Street
Avon Park, Fla.                      Thursday, 10-22-'59
Darling Tafern,

 I never realized before how important my front door is! I locked it yest. aft when I went to Old Settler's and can't get it open.  A lock smith is working on it now, so I hope to be able to open it again soon. Took him 20 minutes, charged a dollar.
 Old Settlers was a big success! The day began lowry but turned out beautifully. Met ever so many old friends, and all commented on my health and longevity. One

youngish woman told me that when she was married I baked a mulberry pie and gave it to them!  I had forgotten all about it. Mildred Wray came over for the celebration
and took me there, and Mrs. Godwin brought me home. Cora

went home with Mildred for a week or so.    Mrs. Sikes reminded me that Hallowe'en is next and they will be after me. Everybody was very nice and helpful and I had a good time, But I ate something that burned my stomach so it felt on fire. I didn't eat supper, but took my bath and went to bed about seven o'clock. Drank a lot of water and soon went to sleep. Feel fine this a.m.

 The beautiful socks, the m.o. for $15 and your dear letter came promptly. So glad your plane trips were pleasant, and that you felt rested after your vacation. With me

it is a delicious memory. Next time, if I'm still alive, you must come a little later so you can take in the Old Settler's 3rd Wed in Oct - and the Hallowe'en festival.

  Much, much love,  Mother.

something was delivered, couldn't see for the royal poinciana tree that shuts off the view.
5:25 a.m. Thursday    Couldn't go back to sleep, so decided I'd finish this. Thanks for Lucille's picture! I didn't mean that I had none of hers, but none taken

 I'm glad of the nice note to you from Clara. I hope she has a good mate, and will be a good mother to Jr. and Marlene.

 The integration question is a very complicated one. The Negroes need education in order to vote. Many can't sign their names and now that voting machines are being used, they must be able to do that. So it seems to me the schools are the most important. Southern workers don't want the Negroes to be educated. They want to feel above somebody,

and they can't if the Negroes are equal to them - With Faubus it's a question of "saving face".  I hope he gets the penalty he deserves, and Eisenhower has never shown his weakness and lack of intelligence more than in his bargaining with Faubus about the question.  I'm banking on Judge Davies to put Faubus where he belongs.

This afternoon before a heavy shower, I drowned the old white Angora tomcat that has been hanging around here for several days, full
of fleas and mange. I had asked two men to do away with him, but they were too chicken hearted. So I concluded I'd have to do it myself.

talk to him soothingly and tell him it will

I wish you would, when you have time, go to some of those commission houses in Chi - and learn what you can about shipping live poultry to them, what they pay, how they want it shipped if they take, shipping weight ours or their own - Poultry, you know, shrinks a great deal in even one night if not fed and the question of weight is therefore a very important one.  I can see all the kinds of possibilities in the poultry business and when "you all" get tired of trying to make people buy something they don't want you had better join us and see how much easier it is to get them to buy something they do want. - You may also learn what you can about the market for dressed poultry. Dear Girlie:- Am sending you another chicken. This chicken is a yearling and will need more cooking but will go much further as you can make biscuits and gravy for it. It will probably take 2 1/2 to 3 hrs to cook it. Turn your gas low and keep it just at the boiling point until done. Let me know which you like best yearlings or springs and hereafter I will be governed accordingly. 

  Max gave me your letter to read. I think it will be very nice for you to go to Florida. I note what you say about working here. We have not wanted you here to work harder than you now are.
